meanings.def: to hit somebody/something hard with your fist (= closed hand)
examples: punch somebody/something He was kicked and punched as he lay on the ground.
He was punching the air in triumph.
punch somebody/something in/on something She punched him on the nose.
I punched the pillow in frustration.
His attacker had punched him hard in the face.
She playfully punched him on the arm.
He punched the other boy in the stomach.

meanings.def: to make a hole in something with a punch or some other sharp object
examples: punch something to punch a time card
punch something in/through something The machine punches a row of holes in the metal sheet.

meanings.def: to press buttons or keys on a computer, phone, etc. in order to operate it
examples: I punched the button to summon the elevator.

meanings.def: to be or try to be more successful than others in doing something that normally requires more skill, experience, money, etc. than you have
examples: This player seems to be able to constantly punch above his weight.
He punched above his weight as the party’s foreign affairs spokesman.

idioms.def: to be or try to be more successful than others in doing something that normally requires more skill, experience, money, etc. than you have
examples: This player seems to be able to constantly punch above his weight.
He punched above his weight as the party’s foreign affairs spokesman.

meanings.def: a hard hit made with the fist (= closed hand)
examples: a punch in the face
Hill threw a punch at the police officer.
a knockout punch
He shot out his right arm and landed a punch on Lorrimer's nose.
Be careful what you say or you'll get a punch on the nose.
He can throw a powerful punch.
a boxer who knows how to take a punch
(figurative) This policy will deliver a knockout punch to the tourism industry.
It's a well-constructed crime story, told with speed and punch.

meanings.def: a tool or machine for cutting holes in paper, leather or metal
examples: a hole punch

meanings.def: a hot or cold drink made by mixing water, fruit juice, spices and usually wine or another alcoholic drink
to get or do something before somebody else can
to be capable of hitting somebody very hard
to have a powerful effect on somebody
examples: The advertising campaign packs quite a punch.

meanings.def: to express something less strongly than you are able to, for example to avoid upsetting or shocking somebody
examples: Her articles certainly don't pull any punches.

meanings.def: to adapt yourself to a difficult situation

idioms.def: to get or do something before somebody else can
to be capable of hitting somebody very hard
examples: The advertising campaign packs quite a punch.

idioms.def: to express something less strongly than you are able to, for example to avoid upsetting or shocking somebody
examples: Her articles certainly don't pull any punches.

idioms.def: to adapt yourself to a difficult situation

meanings.def: a British humorous magazine, established in 1841, which took its name from the character Punch in Punch and Judy shows. It became Britain's leading magazine for humorous political and social comment, and included drawings by famous artists such as John Tenniel. It was originally published every week. In the 1980s it began losing readers to other magazines such as Private Eye. It stopped appearing in 1992 but appeared again from 1996 to 2002.

examples: Now he’s passed his driving test, he’s as pleased as Punch.
Now he’s passed his driving test, he’s as pleased as Punch.
